course.subject: ECON
course.name: International Trade and Investment
course.description: This course will cover the patterns and the mechanisms of international trade and foreign investment. Topics include the patterns of international trade, why nations trade, what they trade, and who gains from trade, without explicit policy interventions; the determinants and the implementations of different trade policies, the motives for countries or organizations to restrict or regulate international trade, and the welfare implications of those trade policies; the role of firms in the global economy, the operations of multinational enterprises, outsourcing, as well as the patterns and the determinants of foreign direct investment.
course.prerequisites: (ECON 3014 OR ECON 3113) AND (ECON 2123 OR ECON 3123)
course.exclusions: ECON 4384 (prior to 2018-19)

reviews.author: H.W.
reviews.title: Good contents but grumpy professor (Online)
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly talks about international trade, the political economy of trade and trade policies. I think the investment part will be taught in another course (4374).

The course consists of two parts. Part I discusses the pattern of international trade, why nations trade, what they trade, and who gains from trade. Part II analyzes the motives for countries to implement policies that restrict international trade and the welfare implications of those trade policies.

You should get the required textbook; Krugman, Obstfeld and Melitz, International Trade: Theory and Policy, eleventh edition, Pearson Publisher. It will be very helpful for studying as he basically follows the textbook.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think he is okay with his teaching though, he has a very bad temper. Take the midterm rehearsal, for example, the real midterm roughly took 1.5  hours, but he spent nearly 2 hours to rehearse. Quite a waste of time. Moreover, you will get distracted during exams (zoom), as he'll keep nagging.

The TA is not helpful at all, but he is friendly and responsive. He has no idea how to explain the questions we ask, nor the assignments. He told us that he has no prior knowledge of this course, so we'd better ask the professor if we have questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
- Final Examination 40% (covers all chapters)
- Mid-term exam 1 22.5%
- Mid-term exam 2 22.5%
- Homework assignments 10%
- Participation 5%

The grading is pretty fair.
Make sure to get familiar with the assignments, especially for the calculation part. They will be accounted for 30-50 % in the exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
Appropriate for a 4-credit Econ course. 5-6 assignments, 2 midterms and a final. The attendance is not strict at all. Many people never show up in class.   

He will use the tutorial for lectures (roughly every 2 weeks)

去到中後期prof 都解得好清楚，本身又無乜equation，佢用文字講就易搞。

Prof 既口音同動作都好似機械人刻意訓練過咁，但絕對聽得明。有時佢一路拎住個無開既咪講野，變相擋住哂佢d聲。佢好關心學生，成日叫我地去搵佢，傾project，升學，搵工都無任歡迎。

PS Prof 對衣著有無比既堅持

reviews.author: oscarswt
reviews.title: ECON4364 Review
reviews.comment_content: The content is pretty interesting if you are interested in International Trade. The professor always asked thought-provoking questions, such as there is a theory that there will be more trades between two countries if they are having a shorter distance, intuitively the effect should be lower in the modern day with the advanced technology and transportation. However, in reality, the effect is strengthening. She asked 3-4 these kind of questions per lesson, which I find quite interesting. Before Mid term, the content and concept is much harder, you MUST have a good understanding on the correlation between wage, price, labor: capital ratio. It sounds simple but the questions can be really tricky when she added different scenarios. The content after mid term is much easier. Mostly, it focuses on different trade instruments.
reviews.comment_teaching: The best professor I have ever meant in HKUST. She poured all her time and resources on this course. I am sure that you can feel her passion and she is willing to spend time to explain any class content or giving you some career advice. Her explanation is clear that I understand most of the content during the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair. I got a mean for my midterm while I am 5 marks above the mean for my final and at last I got B+.

1. Problem Sets (Assignments)10%
2. Participation 10%
3. Group Projectand Presentation30%
4. One Midterm Examand One Final Exam (CUMULATIVE)50%
5. Research Paper * 0%

Attendance is required
reviews.comment_workload: Extremely huge amount of workload! The professor has warned you during the add drop period. There is a lot of homework, as she got some so-called participant marks, which basically are homework. While you need to have the actually home work, so its a double for the amount of homework. And you need spend quite a lot of time on the project. On the day of presentation, you need to stay from 9 am to 6 pm, with your camera opened and you need to give comments on every group

reviews.author: Anonymous X
reviews.comment_content:
The course consists of two major parts. Part 1 is about different trade theories and trade pattern analysis (including quite some graph analysis and calculations which will be heavily tested in the exams). Part 2 is on policy analysis which is more fun and practical. It's a good balance of quantitative analysis and qualitative understandings - will recommend if you're interested in international trade (especially under the current trade war environment).
One of the highlights of the course compared to other ECON courses is that you get to complete a group project of your chosen topic. It provides some hands-on practice of the trade theories and models learned in class and helps you to develop a more in-depth understanding of international trade.
Plus, it's also a good opportunity if you have ECON4670 to fulfill (for ECON-major students)
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is quite clear. Prof is very experienced and renowned in international trade. She is also a very caring prof, constantly offering her students with guidance on grad school/ job hunting and outside-of-classroom advice.
reviews.comment_grading:
70% exams (midterm+final) + 20% group project & presentation + 10% in-class participation.
Overall it's quite hard to get A range even if you have a decent group project and above-mean exam scores (half-SD above). So you should only take this course for its content instead of the grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Varies with individual choices because problem sets are optional. But the course material is quite intensive so it requires a fair amount of self-study time. Also, the project requires quite some time in group meetings and meetings with prof.

reviews.author: Nicole0425
reviews.title: Good course and good prof
reviews.comment_content:
The course content is in two parts. (copied from syllabus)
1. Part I discusses the patterns of international trade, why nations trade, what they trade, and who gains from trade, without explicit policy interventions.
2. Part II analyzes the determinants and the implementations of different trade policies, the motives for countries or organizations to restrict or regulate international trade, and the welfare implications of those trade policies.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good professor! One of the best that I've had in UST. She is very passionate and always willing to offer help. She welcomes students to arrange meetings with her to discuss the projects. For our group, she gave us a lot of useful advice and guided us on how to conduct research and do our project. After class, she always stays there for q&a. She also arranged many sessions of career talk by her past students (although I didn't have time for most of the talks...). You can feel that she really cares for her students!
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is pretty fair.
4 Problem sets 10%
Participation 10%
one midterm and one final 50% (final is cumulative)
Group project and presentation 30% (outline 2%, ppt slides 10%, presentation 10%, peer evaluation 8%)
4670 paper 0%

-Midterm I got more than 1 SD above mean
-Final I got the highest score of the class
-Homework full marks
-Answered a few questions in class and missed one post-lecture assignment
Eventually got an A+!
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is heavy. She assigned post-lecture assignments every week and gave a limited time to complete. If you do not focus in class, you wouldn't know how to do it.
The group project was fine. She gave us a lot of time to work on it. Only requires more time and effort before handing in the slides and the presentation day. Our group spent quite a lot of time working on the project before the deadline.
For the exams, I spent a lot of time reviewing and watching all the lecture videos. I think the exam itself is not that hard once you understand the concepts and carefully read the questions. The questions can be tricky. All open-book, so it's not that difficult as long as you have everything on your notes.
